THE YEAR IN PICTURES: DRUMBEAT FOR WAR

docs.snippet: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that he was ordering more American troops to search the caves of Tora Bora, and described the effort as crucially important for capturing die-hard members of Al Qaeda, seizing their weapons and uncov...
docs.lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that he was ordering more American troops to search the caves of Tora Bora, and described the effort as crucially important for capturing die-hard members of Al Qaeda, seizing their weapons and uncovering intelligence on terror attacks now being planned. The extra troops, perhaps numbering in the hundreds, would be joined by troops from other nations and by local Afghan militia, Pentagon officials said.
docs.abstract: Sec Donald Rumsfeld orders more American troops to search caves of Tora Bora, Afghanistan, to capture die-hard members of Al Qaeda; he and Pres Bush explain strategy; map (M)

headline.main: More American Troops Are Ordered to Join Cave-to-Cave Search for Al Qaeda
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE GROUND WAR

docs.snippet: An American military tanker plane carrying seven marines crashed into a mountainside and exploded during its final approach to an airfield in southwestern Pakistan today, killing all aboard, the Pentagon said.     The aircraft, a Marine Corps KC-1...
docs.lead_paragraph: An American military tanker plane carrying seven marines crashed into a mountainside and exploded during its final approach to an airfield in southwestern Pakistan today, killing all aboard, the Pentagon said. The aircraft, a Marine Corps KC-130 Hercules, had left Jacobabad, Pakistan, and was on its way to an airfield at Shamsi, 140 miles south of the Afghan border, that has become a supply hub and staging base for marines moving in and out of southern Afghanistan.
docs.abstract: Marine Corps tanker plane crashes into Pakistani mountainside en route to Afghan border, killing all 7 marines aboard, in apparent accident; military officials say they have no evidence plane came under hostile fire; Pres Bush comments; allied jets continue to bomb Al Qaeda's Zhawar Kili base in eastern Afghanistan; Defense Department says underground complex is much larger than previously thought, raising concern that similar sophisticated complexes might exist elsewhere in Afghanistan and shelter Al Qaeda and Taliban forces seeking to regroup; seven marines killed are Capts Matthew W Bancroft and Daniel G McCollum, Sgts Stephen L Bryson, Scott N Germosen and Nathan P Hays, Cpl Bryan P Bertrand and Sgt Jeannette L Winters, first woman among American forces killed since Afghanistan war began (M)

headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE AIR WAR

THE YEAR IN PICTURES: DRUMBEAT FOR WAR

docs.snippet: As a teenager, Wilbur Chapman's youngest son, Nathan, gravitated toward jet skiing and snowboarding and the sort of high-adrenaline diversions some people consider risky. So when Nathan Chapman joined the Army, a decision that startled his parents...
docs.lead_paragraph: As a teenager, Wilbur Chapman's youngest son, Nathan, gravitated toward jet skiing and snowboarding and the sort of high-adrenaline diversions some people consider risky. So when Nathan Chapman joined the Army, a decision that startled his parents, he sought the riskiest assignments, first becoming a Ranger and later a Green Beret. ''He would do things other people might consider dangerous or living on the edge,'' Mr. Chapman said today of his son's penchant for adventure.
docs.abstract: Profile of Sgt First Class Nathan Ross Chapman, who is first American serviceman killed in Afghanistan by enemy fire; photo (M)

headline.main: Soldier and Son Who Thrived On Risk and Army Discipline
